etymologies: late Middle English; earliest use found in The Wycliffite Bible (early version). From classical Latin scrīptiōn-, scrīptiō action of writing down, something written down, spelling, something laid down or specified (by a law), (with reference to literary works, letters, or documents) action of writing, piece of literary composition from scrīpt-, past participial stem of scrībere to write + -iō

definitions: A written text; a piece of writing; especially an inscription. Now rare (poetic in later use).
The physical process (as opposed to the art) of writing.

notes.text: Frequently in translations of or with reference to the works of the French literary theorist Roland Barthes (1915–80).
